name: Avery Ramos
description: Avery Ramos is a 31-year-old operations coordinator in Austin who treats console gaming as both a ritual and a creative outlet. They own a PS5 and Switch, keep an Xbox Series X for Game Pass discovery, and track upcoming releases through calendars, wishlist alerts, and a neatly maintained backlog board. Avery plays most weeknights from 9–11 pm, with a longer Sunday morning session reserved for deep narrative progress. They keep one single-player story and one evergreen multiplayer game in rotation to match mood and time constraints. Avery gravitates toward action-adventures, immersive sims, and indie darlings, prioritizing performance mode at 60 fps but switching to fidelity for photo mode sessions. Comfort replays are a staple; every year they revisit a small set of favorites to benchmark new patches, haptic tweaks, and their own skill growth. A thoughtful host, Avery runs spoiler-safe discussion threads in a small Discord, organizes couch co-op nights, and writes succinct, spoiler-light micro-reviews in Notion that capture mechanics, accessibility options, and “vibe” in 300 words or less. They enjoy trophy hunting to about 70–80% completion, avoiding grindy platinums unless the game truly clicks. Hardware and presentation matter: Avery calibrates HDR for each title, rotates and labels controller batteries, and keeps a lean capture gallery for share-worthy clips. They collect select art books and soundtrack vinyls, favor physical editions for cherished series, and go digital for day-one convenience. Above all, Avery values games as stress relief and storytelling, balancing curiosity for new releases with the comfort of returning to worlds that feel like home.
example_behaviours: Maintains a Notion board for backlog, release dates, and completion percentages
Runs a “two-stack” rotation: one narrative single-player and one multiplayer staple
Hosts monthly couch co-op pizza nights with a second controller always charged
Calibrates HDR and audio profiles per game; labels settings in a shared Google Doc
Switches between performance and fidelity modes based on combat vs photo sessions
Keeps a yearly “comfort replay” list (e.g., one action-adventure, one platformer)
Writes 300-word spoiler-light micro-reviews after each completion
Tracks trophy/achievement goals per game and skips grindy ones beyond a time cap
Uses a pre-release ritual: preloads, clears cache space, updates controllers, checks day-one patch notes
Curates a capture gallery and posts a single best clip per game to avoid clutter
Collects select steelbook editions and vinyl soundtracks for favorite franchises
Participates in spoiler-tagged Discord threads with clear chapter boundaries
Schedules “Backlog Night” midweek to reduce impulse buying during sales
Experiments with controller layouts and haptics, documenting preferred schemes
Runs seasonal retro weekends to revisit older console generations and compare QoL updates
